<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The workspace is empty. I need to create a Storybook instance from scratch. Storybook typically works with a frontend framework like React, Vue, Angular, etc. Since the user hasn't specified a framework, I'll go with React as it's the most common choice.

I'll need to:
1. Initialize a new project (using Vite + React as it's modern and fast)
2. Add Storybook to it

Let me use the Storybook CLI to initialize everything. The recommended way is to use `npx storybook@latest init` but that works best when there's already a project. For a completely new project, I should:

1. Create a Vite + React project first
2. Then add Storybook

Or I can use `npx storybook@latest init --builder vite` with some options.

Actually, let me create a simple Vite React project first, then add Storybook to it. This is the cleanest approach.</details></think>

---

The workspace is empty, so I'll create a fresh Storybook instance with React and Vite. Let me set this up for you.

```diff
+ export const Button = ({ primary, backgroundColor, size, label, ...props }) =&gt; {
+   const mode = primary ? 'storybook-button--primary' : 'storybook-button--secondary'
+   return (
+     &lt;button
+       type="button"
+       className={['storybook-button', &#96;storybook-button--${size}&#96;, mode].join(' ')}
+       style={backgroundColor &amp;&amp; { backgroundColor }}
+       {...props}
+     &gt;
+       {label}
+     &lt;/button&gt;
+   )
+ }
+ 
+ Button.propTypes = {
+   primary: PropTypes.bool,
+   backgroundColor: PropTypes.string,
+   size: PropTypes.oneOf(['small', 'medium', 'large']),
+   label: PropTypes.string.isRequired,
+   onClick: PropTypes.func,
+ }
+ 
+ Button.defaultProps = {
+   backgroundColor: null,
+   primary: false,
+   size: 'medium',
+   onClick: undefined,
+ }
```

### Available Scripts
- **`npm run storybook`** - Start Storybook dev server (port 6006)
- **`npm run build-storybook`** - Build static Storybook for deployment
- **`npm run dev`** - Run the Vite dev server
- **`npm run build`** - Build the app for production

### Included Features
- **React 18** with Vite for fast HMR
- **Storybook 7** with essential addons:
  - `addon-essentials` (controls, actions, viewport, backgrounds, docs)
  - `addon-interactions` (play functions & testing)
  - `addon-links` (link between stories)
  - `addon-onboarding` (guided tour)
- **Sample Button component** with multiple stories (Primary, Secondary, Large, Small)

```diff
@@ -1,1 +1,145 @@
- 
+ # Storybook Component Library
+ 
+ A modern React component library built with [Storybook](https://storybook.js.org/) and [Vite](https://vitejs.dev/).
+ 
+ ## ğŸš€ Getting Started
+ 
+ ### Prerequisites
+ 
+ - Node.js 18+
+ - npm or yarn
+ 
+ ### Installation
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+ npm install
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ### Development
+ 
+ **Start Storybook** (recommended for component development):
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+ npm run storybook
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ Opens Storybook at [http://localhost:6006](http://localhost:6006)
+ 
+ **Start the app**:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;bash
+ npm run dev
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ## ğŸ“ Project Structure
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ â”œâ”€â”€ .storybook/
+ â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ main.js           # Storybook configuration
+ â”‚   â””â”€â”€ preview.js        # Global decorators &amp; parameters
+ â”œâ”€â”€ src/
+ â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ components/       # UI components
+ â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Button.jsx
+ â”‚   â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Button.css
+ â”‚   â”‚   â””â”€â”€ Button.stories.jsx
+ â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ App.jsx
+ â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ main.jsx
+ â”‚   â””â”€â”€ index.css
+ â”œâ”€â”€ index.html
+ â”œâ”€â”€ vite.config.js
+ â””â”€â”€ package.json
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ## ğŸ“ Writing Stories
+ 
+ Stories are files that end in &#96;.stories.jsx&#96;. Each story represents a different state of your component.
+ 
+ ### Basic Story Structure
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;jsx
+ import { MyComponent } from './MyComponent'
+ 
+ export default {
+   title: 'Components/MyComponent',
+   component: MyComponent,
+   tags: ['autodocs'],
+ }
+ 
+ export const Default = {
+   args: {
+     label: 'Hello World',
+   },
+ }
+ 
+ export const Variant = {
+   args: {
+     label: 'Different State',
+     variant: 'secondary',
+   },
+ }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ ### Adding a New Component
+ 
+ 1. Create your component in &#96;src/components/&#96;:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;jsx
+ // src/components/Card.jsx
+ export const Card = ({ title, children }) =&gt; (
+   &lt;div className="card"&gt;
+     &lt;h2&gt;{title}&lt;/h2&gt;
+     {children}
+   &lt;/div&gt;
+ )
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ 2. Create a stories file:
+ 
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;jsx
+ // src/components/Card.stories.jsx
+ import { Card } from './Card'
+ 
+ export default {
+   title: 'Components/Card',
+   component: Card,
+   tags: ['autodocs'],
+ }
+ 
+ export const Default = {
+   args: {
+     title: 'Card Title',
+     children: 'Card content goes here.',
+   },
+ }
+ &#96;&#96;&#96;
+ 
+ 3. View it in Storybook at [http://localhost:6006](http://localhost:6006)
+ 
+ ## ğŸ› ï¸ Available Scripts
+ 
+ | Command | Description |
+ |---------|-------------|
+ | &#96;npm run storybook&#96; | Start Storybook dev server on port 6006 |
+ | &#96;npm run build-storybook&#96; | Build static Storybook for deployment |
+ | &#96;npm run dev&#96; | Start Vite dev server |
+ | &#96;npm run build&#96; | Build app for production |
+ | &#96;npm run preview&#96; | Preview production build |
+ 
+ ## ğŸ“¦ Included Addons
+ 
+ - **[@storybook/addon-essentials](https://storybook.js.org/docs/essentials/introduction)** - Controls, actions, viewport, backgrounds, docs
+ - **[@storybook/addon-interactions](https://storybook.js.org/docs/writing-tests/interaction-testing)** - Play functions &amp; interaction testing
+ - **[@storybook/addon-links](https://storybook.js.org/docs/sharing/linking-stories)** - Link between stories
+ 
+ ## ğŸ”— Useful Links
+ 
+ - [Storybook Documentation](https://storybook.js.org/docs)
+ - [Writing Stories](https://storybook.js.org/docs/writing-stories)
+ - [Args &amp; Controls](https://storybook.js.org/docs/essentials/controls)
+ - [Autodocs](https://storybook.js.org/docs/writing-docs/autodocs)
+ - [Vite Documentation](https://vitejs.dev/guide/)
+ 
+ ## ğŸ“„ License
+ 
+ ISC
```

The `src/stories/` folder contains Storybook's default example UI/components that they add to help users learn. It's not meant to be "the UI" - it's just examples.

I should clarify this for the user:
1. `src/stories/` - Default Storybook examples (can be deleted)
2. `src/components/` - Where I suggested putting your real components

They can organize it however they want, but typically you'd either:
- Keep components and stories together in `src/components/` 
- Or keep components in `src/components/` and stories in a separate `src/stories/` folder

---

Great observation! Here's what's happening:

**`src/stories/`** â€” This is Storybook's **default example folder** that gets auto-generated when you init Storybook. It contains sample components (Button, Header, Page) to demonstrate how Storybook works. **You can delete this entire folder** if you don't need the examples.

**`src/components/`** â€” This is where I put your **actual components**. I created a Button there as a starting point for your real component library.

### You Have Two Options:

**Option 1: Keep stories with components (recommended)**
```
src/components/
â”œâ”€â”€ Button/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Button.jsx
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Button.css
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ Button.stories.jsx   â† story lives with component
â”œâ”€â”€ Card/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Card.jsx
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ Card.stories.jsx
```

**Option 2: Separate stories folder**
```
src/
â”œâ”€â”€ components/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Button.jsx
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ Card.jsx
â”œâ”€â”€ stories/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Button.stories.jsx   â† stories in separate folder
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ Card.stories.jsx
```

_**User (2026-01-09 21:29Z)**_

got it, can I create new components directly from storybook interface? Or it's just for view and copy the code?

---

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user is asking if they can create new components directly from the Storybook interface. The answer is no - Storybook is primarily a **viewer/documentation tool** for components, not a component creation tool.

Storybook is for:
- Viewing components in isolation
- Testing different states/variants via controls
- Documenting component usage
- Visual testing

You create components in your code editor (like Cursor), and Storybook automatically picks them up based on the file patterns defined in `.storybook/main.js`.

I should clarify this for the user.</details></think>

---

Storybook is **just for viewing and documenting** â€” you can't create components from its interface.

### The Workflow

1. **Create components in your code editor** (Cursor, VS Code, etc.)
   - Write `MyComponent.jsx`
   - Write `MyComponent.stories.jsx`

2. **Storybook auto-detects them** and displays them in the sidebar

3. **Use Storybook to:**
   - ğŸ‘€ View components in isolation
   - ğŸ›ï¸ Tweak props via Controls panel
   - ğŸ“‹ Copy code snippets from the Docs tab
   - ğŸ§ª Test different states/variants
   - ğŸ“– Share documentation with your team

### Quick Component Creation

Since you're in Cursor, you can just ask me to create new components! For example:

> "Create a Card component with title, description, and image"

And I'll generate:
- `Card.jsx` â€” the component
- `Card.css` â€” styles  
- `Card.stories.jsx` â€” stories for Storybook

Then it'll instantly appear in Storybook when you refresh.

Want me to create any components for you?

_**User (2026-01-09 21:29Z)**_

_**Agent (model claude-4.5-opus-high-thinking, mode Agent)**_

<think><details><summary>Thought Process</summary>
The user is asking about folder organization - whether each component should have its own folder containing its files (Button.jsx, Button.css, Button.stories.jsx) rather than having all files flat in the components folder.

This is a common pattern called "component folder" or "feature folder" structure. Both approaches work, but having each component in its own folder is generally cleaner as the project grows.

I should explain both options and offer to reorganize if they want.</details></think>

---

That's a great practice! Having each component in its own folder keeps things organized as your library grows.

### Current (flat structure)
```
src/components/
â”œâ”€â”€ Button.css
â”œâ”€â”€ Button.jsx
â””â”€â”€ Button.stories.jsx
```

### Recommended (component folders)
```
src/components/
â”œâ”€â”€ Button/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ index.jsx         â† exports the component
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Button.jsx
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Button.css
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ Button.stories.jsx
â”œâ”€â”€ Card/
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ index.jsx
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Card.jsx
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ Card.css
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ Card.stories.jsx
```

The `index.jsx` file lets you import cleanly:
```jsx
// With index.jsx
import { Button } from './components/Button'

// Without (have to specify file)
import { Button } from './components/Button/Button'
```

I can move your Button into a `Button/` folder with an index file. Just say the word!

```diff
+ export const Button = ({ primary, backgroundColor, size, label, ...props }) =&gt; {
+   const mode = primary ? 'storybook-button--primary' : 'storybook-button--secondary'
+   return (
+     &lt;button
+       type="button"
+       className={['storybook-button', &#96;storybook-button--${size}&#96;, mode].join(' ')}
+       style={backgroundColor &amp;&amp; { backgroundColor }}
+       {...props}
+     &gt;
+       {label}
+     &lt;/button&gt;
+   )
+ }
+ 
+ Button.propTypes = {
+   primary: PropTypes.bool,
+   backgroundColor: PropTypes.string,
+   size: PropTypes.oneOf(['small', 'medium', 'large']),
+   label: PropTypes.string.isRequired,
+   onClick: PropTypes.func,
+ }
+ 
+ Button.defaultProps = {
+   backgroundColor: null,
+   primary: false,
+   size: 'medium',
```

```
src/components/
â””â”€â”€ Button/
    â”œâ”€â”€ index.jsx          â† exports Button
    â”œâ”€â”€ Button.jsx         â† component logic
    â”œâ”€â”€ Button.css         â† styles
    â””â”€â”€ Button.stories.jsx â† stories
```

The import in `App.jsx` still works as-is:

```jsx
import { Button } from './components/Button'  // âœ“ resolves to Button/index.jsx
```
